description: Visual representation of Ameca, initially located in the Archdiocese of Mexico (now under the Diocese of Guadalajara). Created by an unknown artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Ameca and the surrounding communities and landscape. Centered on the map is the Pueblo de Ameca with its principal church, plaza, jail, and royal houses. Surrounding the plaza and central buildings are the houses of the town of Ameca. A river with various branches is seen throughout the map as well as two ranges of mountains that mark the left and right of the map. The main roads are marked and labeled, reaching outlying cities like Ixcatlan, Guadalajara, las minas de Guachingo, minas de Palmarejo, Mexico, and the province of Avalos. There are a good number of farms and properties shown and corresponding labels of their owners. Some of these include the different wheat farms of Juan Sanchez, Juan Vazquez, Juan Nunez, and Francisco de Mesa. Other farms of livestock include the sheep farms of Uergara, Martin Jurado, and Nuno de Lemos. A few smaller towns depicted include Jayamitlan and Huitzquilic. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Ameca.@en

description: Visual representation of Cuzcatlan, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Cuzcatlan and the surrounding communities and landscape. The principal church and fountain of Cuzcatlan are seen in the upper center of the map. Roads and footpaths lead to the outlying communities that fall within the Cuzcatlan jurisdiction. The towns are represented by either a church or a traditional house and include San Francisco Istlaman (Xitlaman) (S Franco Istlaman (Xitlaman)), Santa María Jujutla (Sta Mra Jujutla), San Martín Mazateopan (S Mín Mazateopan), San Joseph Petlapan (S Joseph Petlapan), Santiago Tilapa (Stiago Tilapa), Santa María Calipan (Sta María Calipan), San Mateo Tlacuchcalco (S Mateo Tlacuchcalco), San Antonio Comulco (S Anto Comulco), San Pedro Otontepetl (S Po Otontepetl), a church without a label, thought to be San Juan Ajusco, and San Jerónimo Asuchitlan. Irrigated fields near prominent rivers are seen throughout the map along with squares representing salt production on the lower half of the map. Toponyms and glyphs are also seen throughout the map. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Cuzcatlan.@en

description: Visual representation of Cholula, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by an unknown artist, the map depicts the administrative capital of Cholula and the surrounding six principal neighborhoods of Cholula. The map is laid out in a grid like fashion with each community represented in a quadrant. The city center of San Gabriel de Cholula is seen in the middle of the map and includes the convent, chapel, and church of San Gabriel, the main plaza, fountain, and marketplace. Each of the six neighborhoods is labeled and depicted with its church and a representative image of a mountain. The rest of the map shows the streets connecting the different neighborhoods and depictions of the houses and other buildings of each area. The six neighborhoods are San Miguel Tecpan, Santiago, San Juan, Santa María, San Pablo, and San Andrés. The principal roads are visible, leading to outlying cities like Mexico City, Huexotzingo (Huejotzingo), and Los Ángeles (Puebla). Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Cholula.@en

description: Visual representation of Zapotitlan, located in the Diocese of Guatemala. Created by Fernando de Niebla, the map depicts the coastline near Zapotitlan and the larger area of Suchitepéquez. Visible at the top of the map are the prominent volcanoes in Guatemala near Quetzaltenango, Lake Atitlan, and Guatemala City as well as the prominent rivers that run towards the Pacific coast from the range of volcanoes. The map shows the towns and villages within the depicted region. The population centers are labeled and include a population count. There is also a large depiction of the map and the region at the bottom of the map. Created in response to questions one and ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Zapotitlan.@en

description: Visual representation of the administrative capital of Acapistla and its surroundings located within the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map illustrates the local water sources and the roads connecting the economic and political center of Acapistla to sixteen surrounding communities. The principal church of Acapistla with its atrium and water well is centered on the map and is surrounded by the smaller communities of Texcala, Atlitiqui, Suchitlan, Zuquiapa, Ayapanco, Itlacan, Tecaxiqui, Tecocuzpa, Zahuatlan, Tetliculuca, Calalpa, Ecatepeque, Zacatepeque, Atlahuymulco, and Pazulco. In addition, four different toponyms are visible along with depictions of mountains and rivers. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Acapistla.@en

description: Visual representation of Atengo and Misquihuala, towns in the archbishopric of Mexico. Created by a local, Indigenous artist, the map illustrates the positioning and boundaries between Santa María de Atengo, Misquiahuala, and Tesontepeque. Outlying, smaller communities are also depicted as well as the landscape and geographical features of the region. Other communities shown are Tecapatepeque, Tula, and Tepeitic (Tepeiti) and the properties listed include Juan de Cabrera, Martín Cerón, and Jerónimo López (Jrmo Lópz). The map also features dozens of glyphs representing communities such as "cerro con cuchillo de pedernal" for Tecpatepec, "Cerro con cuenta de collar" for Cuzcatepec and "Cerro con culebra" for Coatepec. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Atengo y Misquiahuala.@en

description: Visual representation of Cempoala and its surroundings, located within the Archdiocese of Mexico. Cempoala is also known by the indigenous name of Campoli. Created by an unknown indigenous artist, the map features dozens of toponyms, and dozens of glyphs with identifying captions representing natural resources, animals, churches, and other places throughout the depicted region. The map also features thirteen named human figures, representing both Spanish and indigenous people. Featured prominently on the map is the glyph for Campoli, the altepetl, or city-state, of the region. The glyph is of a large hill topped with the drawing of a head of a Totonac (indigenous group of Campoli). Other items to note include the Acueducto del Padre Tembleque and its route that leads to the main church Todos Santos in Campoli, the human figures that are identified and typically associated with a smaller town within the region, and the numerous glyphs that signify the natural resources, animals, and other items of note within the region. Created in response to question ten listed within the relaciones geográficas questionnaire for Cempoala.@en

description: Visual representation of Atlatlauhca, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. The map, created by an unknown artist, depicts the administrative capital of Atlatlauhca and the surrounding communities and landscape. The town of Atlatlauhca is seen at the center of the map with its principal church and a few houses. Two large mountains dotted with trees bookend the town, one being identified as Monte de Atlatlauhca. The region water source is just above the town and the map shows the direction of its flow. Footpaths and roads connect Atlatlauhca to the smaller surrounding communities including Suchiaca (and its mountain), Tenantzinco, Teutenango, Calimaya y Tepemaxalco, and Toluca. The map also includes the two towns of San Pedro (San Po) Cihuatepeque (Cihutepeq) and Epayauhtlan (Epayautla), which are subjects of Tacuba. Also shown is the town of Maxteca, which is a subject of Tenango. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Atlatlauhca.@en

description: Visual representation of the Coatzacualco River and the towns on its banks, located in the province of Coatzacualco in the Diocese of Oaxaca. Drawn by Francisco Stroza Gali, the map covers the full course of the river from the Gulf of Mexico to Utatepeque, which is in the province of Teguantepeque. The depths of the water are calculated at the mouth of the river along the coast and there is detail of the towns closest to the Gulf along with some detail of the coastal features including a lake and mountains. The rest of the map is essentially the course of the river with details including the curves, other smaller branches of the river, and dozens sections of rapids. A few other towns are noted but the map focuses on the river and its course. The towns included are Xaltepeque and Utatepeque. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Coatzacualco.@en

description: Visual representation of Culhuacan, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by Pedro de San Agustín, the map depicts the administrative capital of Culhuacan and its surrounding communities and landscape. Culhuacan is seen with its principal church and nearby pond, paper mill, and a glyph representative of Culhuacan. Footpaths and rivers are visible throughout the map as well as the Cerro de Iztapalapa towards the top of the map. Other communities depicted and labeled include Santiago, San Lorenzo, Santa María, San Andrés, San Pedro, San Sebastián, San Miguel (S Miguel), Santa María Magdalena (Sta María Magdalena), Santa Ana (Sta Ana), San Juan Bautista (S Ju Bautista), Santa Cruz (Sta Cruz), and Santo Bartolomé (Sto Bartolomé). Created in response to question ten listed within the relaciones geográficas questionnaire for Culhuacan.@en

description: Visual representation of Epazoyuca, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by an unknown artist, the map lays out the streets of Epazoyuca in a grid like fashion with the town plaza and church in the center. Most of the other buildings depicted are nondescript dwellings and the streets are also unlabeled. There are several larger roads that are noted with drawn footprints signifying they are more well traveled and connect Epazoyuca with the surrounding areas. At the top of the map is the depiction of a large mountain (Tláloc) which contains the water source for Epazoyuca. The mountain's slopes are adorned with local vegetation including cactus and mazote. At the bottom of the map are rows of irrigated crops. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Epazoyuca@en

description: Visual representation of Huaxtepeque and its surroundings, located within the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by an unknown artist, the map illustrates the local rivers, water sources, vegetation, and the roads connecting the economic and political center of Huaxtepeque to the surrounding communities. Huaxtepeque is centered prominently on the map with a rendering of the Dominican convent and a glyph of a lead tree signifying Huaxtepeque as the altepetl or city-state of the region. Other smaller towns depicted on the map include Teteltzingo, Tetzhuac, Tzacapalco, Ichcatepec, Cocoyoc, and Ayahualco. Other items of note include a glyph representing the local tianguis or market and in the bottom right of the map is a garden of suchinacaztles, a flowering plant. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Huaxtepeque.@en

description: Visual representation of Zacatlan, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the administrative center of Zacatlan and the surrounding communities. Centered on the map is the town of Zacatlan and its church which is connected by roads to the outlying communities. Fifteen communities are represented with traditional houses, but none are labeled on the map. A river is drawn prominently near to Zacatlan along with several plants and a glyph representing the town. Also visible is a prominent fountain near to the church of Zacatlan and a secondary river on the lower half of the map. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Tecolutla, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the port town of Tecolutla and the surrounding area. A cow is featured prominently on the map signifying that this area is one of agriculture and cow pastures. 6 traditional houses are also shown along with a large river labeled as Río de San Pedro y San Pablo (Río Tecolutla). At the bottom of the map the Mar del Norte (Gulf of Mexico) is depicted with a boat and a label saying that the people in this area are fishermen. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

primaryTitle: Pintura de Matlatlan y Chila@es|Pintura de Matlatlan y Chila@en|
description: Visual representation of Matlatlan y Chila, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the administrative centers of Matlatlan and Chila and their surrounding communities. Centered on the map are the two towns of Matlatlan and Chila with their corresponding glyphs. Chila is depicted with a toponym of a chile pepper. A river divides the two administrative centers, essentially dividing the map in two parts: Chila on the top part with its eight surrounding communities and Matlatlan on the lower part with its seven surrounding communities. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Tenanpulco y Matlactonatico, located in Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the towns of Tenanpulco and Matlactonatico and their surrounding communities. Both Tenanpulco and Matlactonatico are labeled and shown with rock foundations and a glyph while the four other surrounding towns are unlabeled. Also seen on the map is a prominent river towards the bottom and a drawing of a large cow with a label saying that this area is one of cow pastures. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Hueytlalpa, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the administrative center of Hueytlalpa and the surrounding communities. Centered on the map is the town of Hueytlalpa and its church which is connected by roads to the outlying communities. Twenty communities are represented with traditional houses, but none are labeled on the map. A river is visible on the left of the map along with a water source near the principal church of Hueytlalpa. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Papantla, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the administrative center of Papantla and the surrounding communities. Centered on the left side of the map is the town of Papantla which is connected by roads to the outlying communities. Three communities are represented with traditional houses, but none are labeled on the map. Papantla is depicted with a glyph and a toponym of a bird. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Jujupango, located in the Diocese of Tlaxcala. Created by Joseph de Velásquez, the map illustrates the administrative center of Jujupango along with the named surrounding communities of Amiztlan, Coayango, Quauhtotola (Quatotola), and Tecpatlan. Each town is depicted with a corresponding glyph and toponym. Roads connecting the towns are visible on the map as well as a couple of water sources. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Hueytlalpa.@en

description: Visual representation of Iztapalapa, located in the Archdiocese of Mexico. Created by Martín Cano, the map illustrates the administrative capital of Iztapalapa and the surrounding communities and landscape. The principal church of Iztapalapa (San Lucas) is prominently placed near the center of the map, directly above the glyph for the city. The houses of the community are seen to the left and the principal roads to Mexico City and Cuitlahuac and Puebla are also visible. The "Laguna grande" (Lake Texcoco) is also seen at the upper left of the map. The surrounding communities depicted and labeled include San Cristóbal (San Cróbal), Santa María, San Juan, Santa Cruz, and San Felipe. Created in response to question ten listed within the relación geográfica questionnaire for Iztapalapa.@en
